text:
Q: Get default remote for git switch A:

Yes you can.

Behavior of git switch is well described in documentation:

Git - git-switch Documentation

--guess
--no-guess

If is not found but there does exist a tracking branch in exactly one remote (call it ) with a matching name, treat as equivalent to

$ git switch -c --track /

If the branch exists in multiple remotes and one of them is named by the checkout.defaultRemote configuration variable, we’ll use that one for the purposes of disambiguation, even if the isn’t unique across all remotes. Set it to e.g. checkout.defaultRemote=origin to always checkout remote branches from there if is ambiguous but exists on the origin remote. See also checkout.defaultRemote in git-config[1].

--guess is the default behavior. Use --no-guess to disable it.

So first you need to list possible branches:

git for-each-ref --format='%(refname)' "refs/remotes/*/my_branch"

Check what what is the default remote (it can be not set):

git config --get checkout.defaultRemote

With this knowledge you can write a script which will determine what will be selected by git switch. Sadly it is not one liner.

Q: Get 'OnDestroy' overrides nothing error when trying to shutdown textToSpeech - Kotlin A:

O of OnDestroy must be in lowercase. See your super call super.onDestroy()

The comment from @Ravi Kumar is correct.

Q: How to open Picker menu when a button is pressed A:

The reason why you are not seeing the round button for the picker is because of the modifier .labelsHidden(). However, it sounds like you don't want a button + picker, you only want a...

microphone button which, when pressed, should open the Picker menu for macOS SwiftUI

This is in fact how a Menu works. So the problem can be solved by wrapping the Picker with a Menu. You can then style the menu button.

The answer to MacOS, SwiftUI - styling Picker button (menu type) shows how this can be done using a custom ButtonStyle (it was my answer). You might want to consider doing it the same way, especially since you might be able to use the same custom style for both the Menu button and the separate video button.

However, it can also be done without factoring out the styling into a separate ButtonStyle:

  1. Wrap the Picker with a Menu.

    • The label that you were using for the Picker can become the label for the Menu instead.
    • Supply a simple string label to the Picker as a replacement.
    • The modifier .labelsHidden() should remain on the Picker.

  2. Change the picker style to .inline.

  3. Apply the style .buttonStyle(.plain) to the Menu.

// DevicePickerButton

var body: some View {
    Menu {
        Picker("Microphone", selection: $selectedDeviceID) {
            // ... picker contents as before
        }
        .pickerStyle(.inline)
        .labelsHidden()
    } label: {
        pickerLabel
    }
    .buttonStyle(.plain)
    .frame(width: 58, height: 58)
    .onHover { hovering in
        if hovering {
            hoverTrigger += 1
        }
        isHovering = hovering
    }
}

Q: How do I configure Notepad++ to use spaces instead of tabs? A:

Go to the Settings > Preferences, and select Language Menu/Tab Settings, depending on your version. Earlier versions use Tab Settings. Later versions use Language. Click the Replace with space check box. Set the size to 4.

See documentation: https://npp-user-manual.org/docs/preferences/#language

Q: pure/const function attributes in different compilers A:
  • GCC: pure/const function attributes
  • llvm-gcc: supports the GCC pure/const attributes
  • Clang: seems to support it (I tried on a simple example with the GCC style attributes and it worked.)
  • ICC: seems to adopt the GCC attributes (Sorry, only a forum post.)
  • MSVC: Seems not to support it. (discussion)

In general, it seems that almost all compilers support the GCC attributes. MSVC is so far the only compiler which does not support them (and which also doesn't have any alternative).

Q: how to send fax in iphone A:

Sending fax is not free, it requires some infrastructure so It is always handled by a third-party service and usually is pretty expensive.

There are two common approaches:

1. Deep link to a faxing app

you can deep link to an existing faxing app.

For example, faxing.app supports deep links where you can pass the destination fax number, there are other services as well you can choose based on your needs. The app opens with the number prefilled, the user sends the fax there, and then returns to your app.

This gives an ok user experience and costs nothing for you to maintain.

2. Integrate a fax API (fax inside your app)

If you want to handle faxing directly inside your app, you need a fax API.

There are many faxing providers with an API you can integrate, where you upload documents and send faxes programmatically. This is a pay-per-fax model and may be overkill in your case.

So basically these are the two options:
- deep link users to a faxing app with the number prefilled, or
- integrate an API and handle faxing inside your app for a per-fax cost.

Q: Can I make `git diff` generate a patch ignoring changes in comments? A:

If comments can be reliably detected, you can encode them as whitespace characters before performing a diff with the -b or -w option, and then decode them in the diff output.

For example, if whitespace characters are \x08, \x09, \x0b, \x0c, \x20, then you could use a base-5 encoding of each source character that is to be ignored. Or for simpler parsing, you could use one character to escape itself elsewhere (perhaps \x20 turns into \x20s), then any run of whitespace that follows an \x20 must be an encoded comment character.

Designing an encoding is straightforward, if tedious.

The tricky bit is detecting comments reliably - in worst case, you need a full parser for the programming language used in the source.

For example, Is there a comment here?

printf("abc \
//blah blah \
xyz")

Simple example of binary encoding with space and tab and GNU diff's "ignore-trailing-space" option:

bash$ enc()( perl -ple 's|//\K.*|join"",map{y/01/ \t/r}unpack"b*",$&|e' )
bash$ dec()( perl -ple 's|//\K.*|pack"(b8)*",$&=~y/ \t/01/r~=/.{8}/g|e' )
bash$ cat >f1 <<'EOD'
//foo
bar
baz
EOD
bash$ cat >f2 <<'EOD'
//foo2
bar2
baz
EOD
bash$ diff -Z <(enc<f1) <(enc<f2) | dec
2c2
< bar
---
> bar2

T
* (trace add-to-end repeat-first)
(ADD-TO-END REPEAT-FIRST)
* (repeat-first '(for whom the bell tolls))
  0: (REPEAT-FIRST (FOR WHOM THE BELL TOLLS))
    1: (ADD-TO-END (FOR WHOM THE BELL TOLLS) FOR)
    1: ADD-TO-END returned (FOR WHOM THE BELL TOLLS FOR)
  0: REPEAT-FIRST returned (FOR WHOM THE BELL TOLLS FOR)
(FOR WHOM THE BELL TOLLS FOR)
*
